data.title: Uncaught HierarchyRequestError: Failed to execute 'appendChild' on 'Node': The new child element ...
data.body:
[Enter steps to reproduce:]

1. ...
2. ...

**Atom**: 1.16.0 x64
**Electron**: 1.3.13
**OS**: Mac OS X 10.12.4
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught HierarchyRequestError: Failed to execute 'appendChild' on 'Node': The new child element contains the parent.

```
At /private/var/folders/8h/y6c3_pz963vbljztph4cf3rw0000gp/T/AppTranslocation/021ED26E-4DE5-49BB-A000-23CAA16A7B79/d/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/line-numbers-tile-component.js:168

Error: Failed to execute 'appendChild' on 'Node': The new child element contains the parent.
    at Error (native)
    at LineNumbersTileComponent.module.exports.LineNumbersTileComponent.setLineNumberInnerNodes (/app.asar/src/line-numbers-tile-component.js:168:29)
    at LineNumbersTileComponent.module.exports.LineNumbersTileComponent.updateLineNumberNode (/app.asar/src/line-numbers-tile-component.js:181:14)
    at LineNumbersTileComponent.module.exports.LineNumbersTileComponent.updateLineNumbers (/app.asar/src/line-numbers-tile-component.js:98:16)
    at LineNumbersTileComponent.module.exports.LineNumbersTileComponent.updateSync (/app.asar/src/line-numbers-tile-component.js:78:19)
    at LineNumberGutterComponent.module.exports.TiledComponent.updateTileNodes (/app.asar/src/tiled-component.js:55:19)
    at LineNumberGutterComponent.module.exports.TiledComponent.updateSync (/app.asar/src/tiled-component.js:18:12)
    at GutterContainerComponent.module.exports.GutterContainerComponent.updateSync (/app.asar/src/gutter-container-component.js:79:25)
    at TextEditorComponent.module.exports.TextEditorComponent.updateSync (/app.asar/src/text-editor-component.js:235:39)
    at /app.asar/src/text-editor-component.js:323:28
    at ViewRegistry.module.exports.ViewRegistry.performDocumentUpdate (/app.asar/src/view-registry.js:219:9)
    at /app.asar/src/view-registry.js:3:59
```

### Commands

```
     -2:33.6.0 core:backspace (input.hidden-input)
     -2:32.6.0 core:save (input.hidden-input)
     -2:28.1.0 core:copy (input.hidden-input)
     -2:23.8.0 core:move-up (input.hidden-input)
     -2:23.5.0 editor:newline (input.hidden-input)
  3x -2:21.9.0 core:backspace (input.hidden-input)
     -2:07.2.0 editor:newline (input.hidden-input)
  7x -1:55.4.0 core:backspace (input.hidden-input)
     -1:50.5.0 core:copy (input.hidden-input)
     -1:49.3.0 core:paste (input.hidden-input)
     -1:33.6.0 core:copy (input.hidden-input)

  3x -0:10.4.0 core:backspace (input.hidden-input)
  2x -0:01.9.0 editor:newline (input.hidden-input)
     -0:01.2.0 core:save (input.hidden-input)
```

### Non-Core Packages

```
atom-html-preview 0.1.22 
atom-material-syntax-dark 0.2.7 
atom-material-ui 1.3.9 
delete-lines 0.5.0 
isotope-ui 2.8.0
```

data.title: apm changes home and thus ignore regulare .gitconfig
data.body: HOME environment has been set to %USERPROFILE%\.atom\.node-gyp during plugin installation, which may provock an failure in plugin installation

data.title: Update application.json only on change
data.body:
### Description

File .atom/storage/application.json is updated with every window context switch. But as there is no change at all in 99% of cases, the only thing that is really changed is modification timestamp of the file.
This is not nice, as it constantly writes to disk when you are switching between application widows.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom and some file in it
2. Switch focus to another program window (even another Atom window)
3. Switch back
4. Switch focus to another program window (even another Atom window)
5. .atom/storage/application.json gets updated (just new timestamp) even though the list of opened "initialPaths" stays the same

**Expected behavior:** 
File application.json should be updated only when there is a change to it's content or when Atom is closing.

**Actual behavior:** 
File application.json gets updated at every focus switch even though there is no change of it's content.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions 
I am now on version below running Fedora 25, but it happens since I started using Atom two years ago on Fedora 21. I hoped it will get fixed eventually, but it still happens.

Atom    : 1.14.4
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.9.3

data.title: White Atom window when I open a file from terminal
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

I did everything except the "Safe Mode" because I can't reproduce the problem constantly and I'm not able to run Atom in safe mode all the day.

### Description

When I open a file doing `cmd` + clicking on a file path in iTerm 2, some times (once a day?) a white window of Atom opens, the "custom titlebar" gets disabled, and I see a new Atom icon in the Dock.

As you can see, the Atom icon in the Dock is different from the custom one I have assigned to my Atom.app.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5382443/25224135/cb0eba9a-25bd-11e7-89a0-3baf38a61f55.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5382443/25224500/da3320f0-25be-11e7-9594-9d8a5f3d9e99.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. `touch /tmp/test.js`
2. `ls /tmp/test.js`
3. CMD + Click on the file path to open Atom

**Expected behavior:** A normal Atom instance should be open.

**Actual behavior:** a white Atom window appears and the custom titlebar is disabled

**Reproduces how often:** few times a day

### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

$ apm --version
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.11.0

macOS 10.12.4 (16E195)
```

### Additional informations
I reproduce the same behavior if I use the `atom` CLI provided by "Atom Shell Commands" and also if I use the `open -a /Applications/Atom.app` command

data.title: Issue building atom on Windows
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

In attempting to build Atom from source on Windows 10, I am presented with an issue that a "path, file name, or both are too long".

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Checkout latest commit (currently 1fc23c3)
2. `script/build --create-windows-installer --compress-artifacts`

**Expected behavior:** Atom builds, providing installer

**Actual behavior:** Build fails during creation of installer

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

OS: Windows 10 Pro x64
Node: v6.10.2
NPM: v3.10.10
Python: 2.7.12

Also, I am using Visual C++ Build Tools 2015.

### Additional Information

My repo is checked out to `c:\atom` to get the path as short as possible. I have run `npm dedupe` on my node_modules in both the repo base and the 'out' directories at different points to attempt to get rid of this error - I am using NPMv3 so I believe this is not needed anyway.

Here is a snippet of the build output with debugging:

    Verifying if snapshot can be executed via `mksnapshot`

    Moving generated startup blob into "C:\atom\out\Atom x64\snapshot_blob.bin"

    Creating Windows Installer for C:\atom\out\Atom x64

    Thu, 20 Apr 2017 03:04:54 GMT electron-windows-installer:fs-utils Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, stat 'C:\atom\out\Atom x64\resources\app.asar'

data.title: Max token length for highlighters is reduced to ~1000 in 1.16
data.body:
Looks like Atom 1.16 stopped highlighting long strings for JavaScript and Python (using MagicPython). Highlighter marks long tokens as invalid or simply stops highlighting, see screenshot below:


### JavaScript

### Python

### Python Multiline

![screen shot 2017-04-19 at 10 04 35 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/239003/25210047/357cee50-254c-11e7-9ca3-a5d3f197210b.png)

![screen shot 2017-04-19 at 10 04 37 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/239003/25210048/358eceae-254c-11e7-89ea-6e65bd4e6c0e.png)

See also https://github.com/MagicStack/MagicPython/issues/79.

data.title: Fix folding key bindings
data.body:
### Description of the Change

The documentation for Linux and Windows says that you need to use `Ctrl+Alt+F` key binding to fold arbitrary sections of your code or text. However, in `linux.cson` and `win32.cson` declared a
`Ctrl-Alt-Shift-[` key binding, which leads to incorrect processing of keystroke and the appearance of duplicates. `Ctrl-Alt-Shift-[` key binding processed as `Ctrl-Alt-{` key binding which is already declared to fold everything.

| Before         | After          |
| :------------: | :------------: |
|![before](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11644685/25205281/67330be6-256a-11e7-83f5-a20c071cae60.png)|![after](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11644685/25205394/fb55e816-256a-11e7-8290-98bd8eedf54d.png)|

### Alternate Designs

None.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Bug fixes.

### Benefits

Correct folding key bindings.

### Possible Drawbacks

None.

### Applicable Issues

#14023

### See Also

http://flight-manual.atom.io/using-atom/sections/folding/

data.title: WSL command line compatability (Creators Update)
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: 
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: 
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions:
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: 
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: 

### Description

Now that [WSL/Windows Interop is officially released](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/interop), would be good to update the Windows Atom wrapper scripts. 

When running "atom" or "apm" inside bash.exe (Windows Creators Update Build 15063.138) the WSL environment isn't detected by the scripts inside %UserProfile%\AppData\Local\atom\bin

WSL's bash.exe environment will call the shell script (as opposed to batch files) by default

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open the WSL environment (<kbd>Win</kbd> + <kbd>R</kbd> + <kbd>`bash.exe`</kbd> + <kbd>Enter</kbd>)
2. Inside WSL environment, open Atom (<kbd>`atom.exe`</kbd>+<kbd>Enter</kbd> 

**Expected behavior:** Expected atom and/or apm to work normally

**Actual behavior:** 

**ATOM**
```
/mnt/c/Users/ryan/AppData/Local/atom/bin/../app-1.16.0/resources/cli/atom.sh: line 9: pwd: -W: invalid option
pwd: usage: pwd [-LP]
'/atom.cmd' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.
```

**APM**

```
/mnt/c/Users/ryan/AppData/Local/atom/bin/../app-1.16.0/resources/cli/../app/apm/bin/apm: line 37: /mnt/c/Users/ryan/AppData/Local/atom/app-1.16.0/resources/app/apm/bin/node: No such file or directory
```

**Reproduces how often:** Every time

### Versions

```
 % **atom --version**
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

 % **apm --version**
Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.15063]
apm  1.16.1
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python
git 2.10.2.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

### Additional Information

For now, it's easy enough to work around this issue by creating an alias in your WSL shell, for example:

```
alias atom='cmd.exe /C C:\\Users\\ExampleUser\\AppData\\Local\\atom\\bin\\atom.cmd'
alias apm='cmd.exe /C C:\\Users\\ExampleUser\\AppData\\Local\\atom\\bin\\apm.cmd'
```

Ideally we could rewrite the wrapper files for the Windows package of Atom to work seamlessly whether running from the Start Menu, cmd.exe, bash.exe, or any of the other Cygwin derived environments. Over the near term, I expect that WSL will replace all of the Cygwin derived environments, greatly simplifying most users development environments.

data.title: Atom 1.16.0 does crash on start on UBuntu 16.04
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

This is probably a duplicate of #14223 but because there is not much information for developers to exactly reproduce ( no OS and atom version specified etc) I decided to start from scratch with a new full issue template.

I downloaded and installed the .deb Package of atom for Ubuntu, but it deoes not start.
When I type "atom" at the command line, I get an application window with the usual menu antries "file, edit, ..," in the background, and a notification window in trhe foreground saying "the editor has crashed" with the options "close window" "reload" "keep it open".

* Close windows leads to the appication closing
* Reload leads to the same thing again
* Keep open leads to showing the main application window previously described with a main area totally empty and thje usual menu - file, edit, view, selection, find, packages, help" - but none of the  entries in each of the main menus does anything.


### Steps to Reproduce

1. run ubuntu 16.04
2. download deb package 1.16.0 and install
3. run "atom" at the command line

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Application starts and can be used to open and edit files etc.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

I get an application window with the usual menu antries "file, edit, ..," in the background, and a notification window in trhe foreground saying "the editor has crashed" with the options "close window" "reload" "keep it open".

* Close windows leads to the appication closing
* Reload leads to the same thing again
* Keep open leads to showing the main application window previously described with a main area totally empty and thje usual menu - file, edit, view, selection, find, packages, help" - but none of the  entries in each of the main menus does anything.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Ubuntu 16.04 with latest updates and backports

$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

$ apm --version
apm  1.16.1
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4


### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: Only trigger branch builds on master and release branches
data.body: ### Description of the Change Modify the Travis, Circle CI, and AppVeyor build metadata to only create branch builds for `master` and release branches named `x.y-releases`. This should help our build queue situation somewhat. Note that _pull request_ builds should still be triggered on all three systems. ### Alternate Designs We could do this by adding logic to the build scripts themselves to detect when they're being executed on a branch build that will also create a PR build, but there's no reason not to use the built-in solutions for this. AppVeyor and (I believe) Circle both allow you to configure this setting in their own web UIs. I generally prefer to keep build configuration within the repository as much as possible, though, it's less confusing and we can manage it with pull requests (like this one!). ### Why Should This Be In Core? The core build metadata files are in core :grin: ### Benefits This will decrease the extraneous builds that are created when maintainers push branches to the atom/atom fork and create pull requests from them, which is [common in our workflow](https://github.com/atom/atom/branches/all). This results in _two_ builds for each push to a feature branch: one from the push to the feature branch and one from the pull request event: Running fewer builds will result in less queue pressure and more rapid feedback on changes. ### Possible Drawbacks Running the tests less often may cause us to miss flaky failures that happen only occasionally. We will also lose the ability to distinguish failures that are present on the branch itself (from the branch build) from those that are caused by the merge into master (from the pull request build). ### Applicable Issues _N/A_ We've agreed to hold off on changing the build for a day or so to more easily isolate the cause of any problems from #13646. /cc @damieng @as-cii @maxbrunsfeld @50Wliu

data.title: Update languages
data.body:
### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

* language-c
  * Punctuation tokenization improvements
  * Tokenize `nullptr` as a constant instead of a variable
  * Fix digit separators
* language-gfm
  * Tokenize embedded GraphQL
  * Add `clj` as alternative to `clojure`
  * Recognize `___` as a hr
* language-go
  * Don't require a word before an opening bracket when indenting
  * Fix multiple issues with variable tokenization
  * Tokenize variables starting with a non-ASCII letter
  * Remove lookbehinds where possible
* language-git
  * Increase maximum subject length to 72
* language-java
  * Tokenize new statements in ternaries
* language-sql
  * Correct time/timestamp grammar matches
* language-json
  * Add `.htmlhintrc` file support
* language-mustache
  * Use injections
  * Add `.mst` file support

### Possible Drawbacks

Possibly some language-go and language-mustache regressions.

data.title: Renaming Opened File in Tree View does not update buffer
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When renaming an opened file using the rename function of the Tree View, the buffer does not update: instead, the old file stays opened in an unsaved state. Saving it creates a new file with the old name.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create file "test.html" in project
2. Open "test.html" so it shows in the main editor screen
3. Right click on the file in Tree View, click rename file and rename it to test2.html

**Expected behavior:** The buffer should update accordingly when renaming the file. The file present in the buffer should be the same file with the new name

**Actual behavior:** The buffer does not update. The old name shows in the tab and the file changes to an unsaved state. Saving the file creates a new file with the old name.

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the time

### Versions

Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.5
git 1.8.3.1

Working on CentOS 7

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

on ubuntu 17.04 discord is no longer installable by conventional means.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. download discord.deb
2. attempt to open with default app (double click, or click chrome download; this opens the software manager) this results in the software manager opening and doing nothing; clicking on install is normally the way to go from there but in this case it has no effect


**Expected behavior:** for discord to install on the system

**Actual behavior:** discord does not install on the system

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

latest current discord.deb from the discord website (18/april/2017 at time of writing). installing to an ubuntu 17.04 64bit uefi (gpt) fresh install no kernel or other modifications.

### Additional Information

the current workaround I found is using gdebi instead of software manager but this cannot be asked to become the norm. as with other software a version compatible with 17.04 will come down the line. or at least I suppose.

data.title: Linting issue from commit cc6e127
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

As of commit cc6e127, a [debugging command](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/cc6e127ec149221871e4e6025616fa6e8118c138/src/tokenized-buffer.coffee#L258) has been added to the codebase which causes script/lint to exit with error.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Pull anywhere after or including cc6e127
2. Build atom
3. Run script/lint

**Expected behavior:** Lint to pass without issue

**Actual behavior:** Lint throws an error on the debugging command

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the time

### Versions

Atom after or including commit cc6e127.

### Additional Information

See here:
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/cc6e127ec149221871e4e6025616fa6e8118c138/src/tokenized-buffer.coffee#L258

data.title: Allows atom to open local files by URL scheme
data.body:
### Description of the Change

The change allows the editor to open local files based on a URL handler. This functionality is common in other editors, such as sublime and emacs

### Alternate Designs

No alternates. Some people have suggested using the 'atom:' scheme, however that is already in use for packages. WizardOfOgz has made a [script](https://github.com/WizardOfOgz/atom-handler) to act like a wrapper around atom, essentially translating a URI scheme to a file and passing it to atom.

Some notable discussions requesting such a feature:
https://discuss.atom.io/t/atom-protocol-handler/13336
Also see issue #2037 

### Why Should This Be In Core?

This can not be implemented in a package as it is, by design, core behaviour.

### Benefits

This shall allow files to be opened by URL. 

### Possible Drawbacks

None.

### Applicable Issues

In my personal use-case, I will be using the PHP Whoops package to handle exceptions in web-development. It will present me with a page with a URL to the file/line/column which I can then click and it will open it straight in the atom editor at the exact point at which the error occured.

### Still to be done
 * [x] Register atm handler with windows - **UNTESTED**
 
* [x] Register atm handler with OSX

data.title: Saving and renaming different files causes conflict
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

File handle conflict detecting file renames, when saving and renaming files at the same time.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. <del>Open a file named `fft.cpp`.</del>
2. <del>Create another empty file, enter something in it, and open the "Save File" dialog, but do not save the file at the moment.</del>
3. <del>Rename the file `fft.cpp` into `fft2.cpp`.</del>
4. <del>Save the newly opened file to the same folder, and call it `fft.cpp`. This wouldn't cause any conflict, as they are mutually different files.</del>
5. <del>**At this point, you may notice, both open tabs turn into `fft2.cpp`.</del>
6. <del>**If you save any of the two files, the other would change its content into this one, rendering the previously available content unreachable.**</del>

As I was alleged of not stating the stati clearly enough, this is a modified version of the reproduction steps.

1. Create a file / open a file **in Atom** whose location is `D:/a.cpp`.
2. **In Atom**, create another file and add arbitrary things in it, then open the `Save File` dialog. **DO NOT INTERACT WITH ATOM AT THE MOMENT.**
3. **IN EXPLORER OR CMD, WHERE YOU WOULD NOT INTERACT WITH ATOM**, rename `D:/a.cpp` to `D:/b.cpp`.
4. **In the Save File dialog**, there should only be a file `b.cpp` on Drive D.
5. **In the Save File dialog**, save the new (empty) file as `D:/a.cpp`.
6. **Currently in Atom**, both open tabs should appear as `b.cpp - D:/`.
7. **IN ATOM**, saving any of the two files would result in the other having its contents change into this one.

**Expected behavior:** The first file should turn its name to `b.cpp`, while the newly saved file should retain its expected name `a.cpp`.

**Actual behavior:** Both files turn into `b.cpp`, and are duplicates of the same *file handle*.

**Reproduces how often:** **This can be reproduced at a rate of 100%, regardless of the file names.**

### Versions

**Affects Atom versions `1.8.x` through `1.16.0`, as far as I am concerned.**

Operating system: Windows 10.0.14393.

### Additional Information

I've never read any of the related code, and decided that there's something to do with the file system journal. Probably this requires a big fix.

**To regulators:** Change the issue title if you consider it inappropriate.

data.title: Atom crash opening a folder, adding a project folder or dragging folder
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The IDE crash when I drag a folder, use the option to open a folder or adding a folder 
I'm on a Windows10 Home edition x64

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom
2. Select option -> Add a Project folder
3. Atom crash

**Expected behavior:** The project tree open on the left

**Actual behavior:** Atom crash and show the message: The editor has crashed, please report this issue to https://github.com/atom/atom and 3 options -Close Window -Reload -Keep it Open

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

It can open single files but not a folder

Everytime it crashes it give the same error in the crash log

> _companyName:GitHub
> _productName:Atom
> _version:1.16.0
> platform:win32
> process_type:renderer
> prod:Electron
> ptime:7859659
> rept:electron-crash-service
> ver:1.3.13

> _companyName:GitHub
> _productName:Atom
> _version:1.15.0
> platform:win32
> process_type:renderer
> prod:Electron
> ptime:14346
> rept:electron-crash-service
> ver:1.3.13

Tried in older versions

If I click in Reload, it just open a new window clean
If I click on Keep it Open stay frozen, waited 20min

This is the operation log
[operation_log.txt](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/926764/operation_log.txt)

I already tried: 
* Reinstalling
* Deleting .atom
* Change .atom to .atom-backup,
* Delete blob-store in .atom
* Delete storage in .atom
* Reinstall and restart computer
* Try on safe mode

If I need to add any more information let me know

data.title: Add Workspace.paneContainerForItem method
data.body: The methods `paneForItem`, `paneForURI`, and `paneContainerForURI` already exist, so it seems reasonable to add `paneContainerForItem` as well. I've also backfilled some tests for these simple methods.
